titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Michele Zackheim Papers
ca. 1900-2000 (Bulk 1992-2000)
MSS 108
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Yookyung Kwon (March-July 2003), Leif Sorensen (July-September 2004), and Melanie Meyers-Cushman (December 2004).

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Zackheim Finding Aid.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2009-07-22T12:15-0400

did.abstract: Writer and visual artist Michele Zackheim is the author of two novels: Violette's Embrace and Einstein's Daughter: the Search for Lieserl. The Michele Zackheim Papers comprise research materials for the novels, including correspondence, manuscripts, legal documents, publicity material, photos, and audio and video cassettes.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Michele Zackheim Papers were donated to the Fales Library on December 18, 2000 by Michele Zackheim.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restrictions. Appointments are necessary to consult archive and manuscript collection materials.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Writer and visual artist, Michele Zackheim is the author of two novels. Violette's Embrace: A Novel (Riverhead Books, 1996), is a fictional biography of the French writer Violette Leduc. Her second novel, Einstein's Daughter: The Search for Lieserl (Penguin Putnam, 1999), follows the mystery of the lost illegitimate daughter of Mileva and Albert Einstein. Zackheim has also worked in the visual arts as a fresco muralist, an installation artist, and a painter. She has received two NEA awards, and has taught at the School of Visual Arts in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Michele Zackheim Papers are a part of the Fales Library/Special Collections, New York University. The Michele Zackheim Papers are comprised of research material, correspondence, manuscripts, legal documents, publicity material, photos, audio and video cassettes. The research materials include a copy of August Forel's "Die Frage Sexuelle" with manuscript annotations by Mileva Maric, which was unearthed during one of Zackheim's visits to Serbia. Also included are research materials from various archival collections and duplicates of many of the legal documents related to Evelyn Einstein's lawsuit against the Einstein Family Correspondence Trust.
SERIES I: Leduc Contains materials related to the production of Zackheim's first novel, Violette's Embrace, a fictional biography of Violette Leduc. Organized in five subseries.
Subseries A: Research Zackheim's research files, arranged alphabetically by author, where applicable, or subject. Includes correspondence and notes.
Subseries B: Manuscripts Various drafts of the book, Violette's Embrace
Subseries C: Legal Release forms securing permission to quote from various sources.
Subseries D: Correspondence Correspondence between Zackheim and a range of correspondents. Arranged alphabetically by correspondent's name.
Subseries E: Publicity Includes materials for readings, mailings and other promotions. Arranged alphabetically by material.
Subseries F: Media Tapes and non-print materials relating to the book.
Subseries G: Photographs Original photographs and copies.
Subseries H: Miscellaneous Other materials from Zackheim's Leduc file.

SERIES II: New Yorker Assignments Comprises research, manuscripts and correspondence related to two proposed articles on the Einstein family for The New Yorker (neither of which was published): one on Lieserl Einstein, the subject of Einstein's Daughter, and one on the legal battles of Evelyn Einstein, with whom Zackheim struck up a friendship during her research on the family. Arranged in four subseries.

Subseries A: Research Research materials specifically related to the two articles (more general research can be found in series 3A). Arranged alphabetically by author, where applicable, or by subject.
Subseries B: Manuscripts Draft versions and proposals for both articles. Arranged by title and then by loose chronology.
Subseries C: Correspondence Correspondence related to the articles, especially with Michele's agent and New Yorker staff and editors.
Subseries D: Miscellaneous Includes expense accounting and invoices.

SERIES III: Einstein Contains materials related to the production of Zackheim's second novel, Einstein's Daughter: The Search for Lieserl, a biography of Einstein's illegitimate daughter, conceived out of wedlock when Einstein and Mileva Maric were students at Zurich Polytechnic Institute. These files were collected over the five year period in which Zackheim investigated the possible fates of Lieserl. Organized into nine subseries.

Subseries A: Research Contains Michele Zackheim's research files (including notes and correspondence) for Einstein's Daughter. The subseries is arranged alphabetically by author when relevant and subject with the exception of Michele Zackheim's note card file and research binders, which can be found at the end of the subseries. Research Binder # 4 consisting of negatives, contact sheets, and photographs was removed to subseries G, box 11.
Subseries B: Manuscripts Comprises drafts, proofs, and corrections to Einstein's Daughter. Arranged in a loose chronology of the drafts.
Subseries C: Legal Documents Contains copyright information, permissions to quote and release forms, arranged alphabetically by type of document.
Subseries D: Correspondence Correspondence to and from a broad range of sources, contacts and informants. Arranged alphabetically by correspondent.
Subseries E: Publicity Includes materials for readings, mailings and other promotions. Arranged alphabetically by material.
Subseries F: Media Includes recorded interviews, one videotape and two zip discs containing research material.

Subseries G: Photographs Contains original photographs of the Einstein family, duplicates of originals, photocopies and pictures documenting Zackheim's research trips, also contains negatives for some of the photographs. Originals and negatives were removed to box 10. Where applicable Zackheim's original notes and annotations have been kept with the original documents.
Subseries H: Administrative Contains invoices and other bookkeeping documents and records.
Subseries I: Miscellaneous Contains miscellaneous materials found in the Einstein files.

SERIES IV: Albert Einstein Family Correspondence Trust Contains legal documents, correspondence and other materials relating to Evelyn Einstein's lawsuit against the trust. Arranged in three subseries.
Subseries A: Legal Documents Includes depositions, wills, declarations, and other legal documents. Arranged alphabetically by party name.
Subseries B: Correspondence Contains correspondence relating to the suit, much of it with Evelyn Einstein's lawyer, Quentin Kopp. Arranged alphabetically by correspondent.
Subseries C: Miscellaneous Contains other materials related to the case including press clippings.

p.emph: SERIES V: Miscellaneous writing assignments and projects

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: There is no information about materials that are associated by provenance to the described materials that have been physically separated or removed.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Michele Zackheim Papers; MSS 108; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.
